questions.question_text: Which of the following is the BEST method for managing information security compliance of third-party suppliers?

choices.B: Conduct a vulnerability assessment of the third-party supplier.
choices.D: Ensure information security requirements are addressed in the contract.
choices.A: Develop specific information security policies for third parties.
choices.C: Include third-party supplier details in the risk register.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
i vote D - Ensure information security requirements are addressed in the contract.
Doesn’t B do a better job of “managing” it than D?

choices.B: The cloud provider's information security manager

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. The organization's data owner

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the BEST course of action when an organization's incident response team does not have expertise in forensic analysis?

choices.C: Conduct a forensic examination of the device.
choices.A: Check for a signed nondisclosure agreement (NDA).
choices.D: Discuss the concern with the employee.

questions.question_text: What should be the FIRST step when investigating an employee suspected of inappropriately downloading proprietary information?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
A. Check for a signed nondisclosure agreement (NDA). - Pretty sure you already know there has been a breach of terms or you wouldn't be concerned. So for me no need to check this.
C. Conduct a forensic examination of the device. - Not necessary at this stage
D. Discuss the concern with the employee. - No because you could alarm them to the fact that you're onto them.

Answer:
B. Review system access logs. - This is the best at this stage as it won't raise the alarm and may gather evidence or otherwise exonerate them.

Selected Answer: B
Ensure/Assure = test, audit, review, etc. The closest to that should be B.
B. Testing the incident response plan

Another shit question:

A. Conducting an incident capability maturity assessment - Not as beneficial as any of the others 
C. Establishing an incident management performance matrix - Helpful. But doesn't do much without a team
D. Assembling the incident response team - Helpful. But who will be in the team, how will they react in an incident. I just wonder if a semi-trained team is better than no team at all...

Answer:
B. Testing the incident response plan - If by implication a team and/or matrix is in place then I assume testing it is the best.
